g.text: Do Not Cite, Quote or Distribute
Technological change and innovation are considered key drivers of economic growth and social
(Brandão Santana et al. 2015; Heeks and Stanforth 2015)
increased production and consumption of goods as well as services create higher demands for improved
Since the Industrial Revolution, however, and notwithstanding the
benefits, this production and consumption trend and the technological changes associated to it have also
come at the cost of long
e support systems of our planet
. The significance of the such impacts depends on the technology, but also on the
trinsic characteristics of the country or region
Other chapters in this volume have discussed technological change in various ways, including as a
framing issue (chapter 1), in the context of specific sectors (chapters
(chapter 12) and as a matter of policy, international cooperation and finance (chapters 13

ral, implicitly or explicitly, technological change is assigned an important role in
climate change mitigation and achieving sustainable development
designed policies, can contribute to achieve mitigation and adaptation
targets along with broader sustainable development goals avoiding, in the process, undesired
The environmental impacts of social and economic activities, including emissions of GHG, are greatly
influenced by the rate and direction of technological changes
usually designed and used to increase productivity and reduce the use of natural resources can lead to
increasing production and consumption of goods and services through different rebound effects that
diminish the potential benefits of reducing the p
Soete 1990; Gossart 2015; Sorrell 2007; Barker et al. 2009)
Those environmental impacts depend not only on which technologies are used, but also on how they
. Technological change is not exogenous to social and economic systems;
technologies are not conceived, selected, and applied autonomously
driving forces of the problem, such as more resource intensive lifestyles and larger populations
the direct and indirect effects of technological changes on physical and social systems could improve
making, also in those cases where tec
A sustainable global future for people and nature requires rapid and transformative societal change by
integrating technical, governance (including participation), financial and societal aspects of the
research from around the world can inform implementation of adapt
benefits and drawbacks of linkages in social
ecological complexity, including externalities and rebound
effects from innovation and technological transformation
Technological change and transitional knowledge can reinforce each other. The value of traditional
wisdom and its technological practices provide examples of sustainable and adaptive systems that could
potentially adapt to and mitigate climate chang
traditional farmers have been able to respond well to climate changes through their wisdom and
e integration of the traditional wisdom with new
technologies can offer new and effective solutions
